perturbation.explanation: Reducing the payment timeframe to one business day contradicts standard business practices and potentially Chinese labor laws concerning payment deadlines, which usually require more reasonable timeframes for processing payments. perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially violates Chinese labor laws regarding reasonable payment processing times and general principles of contract law requiring reasonable notice periods.

perturbation.original_text:
10. Force Majeure

The force majeure hereunder shall mean the natural disaster, war, political event, and adjustment of laws, regulations and state policies. If the performance of this Agreement by one Party or the Parties according to provisions agreed hereunder is directly affected by the force majeure event, the affected Party shall immediately notify the other Party or its attorney-in-fact of the situation of the force majeure event, and shall, within fifteen (15) days, provide the detailed information of the force majeure event or the reason for non-performance or partial performance or delay of performance of this Agreement as well as valid evidence thereof (which shall be issued by the notarization authority at the place where the force majeure event occurs).
perturbation.changed_text:
10. Force Majeure

The force majeure hereunder shall mean the natural disaster, war, political event, and adjustment of laws, regulations and state policies. If the performance of this Agreement by one Party or the Parties according to provisions agreed hereunder is directly affected by the force majeure event, the affected Party shall immediately notify the other Party or its attorney-in-fact of the situation of the force majeure event, and shall, within two (2) months, provide the detailed information of the force majeure event or the reason for non-performance or partial performance or delay of performance of this Agreement as well as valid evidence thereof (which shall be issued by the notarization authority at the place where the force majeure event occurs).
perturbation.explanation: Extending the notification period for a force majeure event to two months contradicts standard practices and may violate principles requiring timely notification in contract law. Delays in providing detailed information about the force majeure event and its impact could significantly harm the other party's ability to mitigate damages or adjust their business strategies.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contradicts principles of timely notification and mitigation of damages in contract law.

perturbation.original_text: 12.7 Any notice or written communication sent by a Party to the other Party under this Agreement shall be made in writing and delivered by courier service or by facsimile accompanied with a confirmation hard copy delivered by courier service. The notice, communication or letter sent under this Agreement shall be deemed as effectively received on the seventh (7) day after sending to the courier service, or shall be deemed as effectively received on the first (1) day after delivered by facsimile, which shall be evidenced by the transmission confirmation.
perturbation.changed_text: 12.7 Any notice or written communication sent by a Party to the other Party under this Agreement shall be made in writing and delivered by standard mail only. The notice, communication or letter sent under this Agreement shall be deemed as effectively received on the thirtieth (30) day after sending to the mail service.
perturbation.explanation: Mandating only standard mail for official notices and setting a 30-day receipt timeframe is unreasonable and conflicts with modern business practices requiring faster communication. This extended period could result in critical delays, breaches of contract due to missed deadlines, and significant financial losses. In the modern digital business landscape, courier and electronic methods are commonly used for faster communication. Making standard mail the only valid method of communication is extremely unusual.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Conflicts with commercially reasonable practices and could violate legal requirements for timely notification in contract law.
